channel.title: Tips & Tricks Archives - The Tech Journalist

item.title: Increase Your Windows 11 Experience With These 5 Hidden Features
item.dc:creator: Jubayar
item.description:
It’s a wonderful time to grasp a number of Windows’ productivity capabilities, whether you’re using your computer for work or personal reasons. From creating Taskbar shortcuts to conserving battery life, these built-in features can assist you. Microsoft is not as forthcoming about its hidden features as Apple is, which might make it harder to work out the way to make use of everything Windows has got to offer. But don’t fear, we have […]

The post Increase Your Windows 11 Experience With These 5 Hidden Features appeared first on The Tech Journalist.
item.content:encoded:
It’s a wonderful time to grasp a number of Windows’ productivity capabilities, whether you’re using your computer for work or personal reasons. From creating Taskbar shortcuts to conserving battery life, these built-in features can assist you. Microsoft is not as forthcoming about its hidden features as Apple is, which might make it harder to work out the way to make use of everything Windows has got to offer. But don’t fear, we have got you covered with an inventory of hidden features that you simply can start using instantly to urge the foremost out of Windows 11.   

So, regardless of whether you have a Microsoft, Dell, HP, or other Windows compatible PC, these helpful hints can help you stay organized and get more done. Also included is all you need to know about Windows 11, including its top features and how it compares to Windows 10. Download Report

1. Open the ‘secret’ Start menu

You know the way to get to the Start menu by pressing the Windows key on your keyboard or the Windows icon at the bottom left of the screen. However, Windows 11 contains a lesser-known second Start menu that makes it much easier to reach critical tools like the Command Prompt, Control Panel, and Task Manager. You may get to it in two ways: by hitting the Windows key + X or by right-clicking the Windows icon/Start button.

2. Open pinned items from your Taskbar with keyboard shortcuts

You don’t have to click the icons to open them if you’ve pinned them to your Taskbar at the bottom of your screen to create a shortcut. Use the keyboard shortcut Windows key + [Number key], where the number key corresponds to the pinned program’s location in the Taskbar. For example, pressing Windows key + 2 on the keyboard will bring up the second pinned item in the Taskbar. Download Report

3. Learn how much space apps are taking up

As computers become more space-constrained, they begin to slow down. Get rid of apps that use up more space than they should, especially if you don’t use them on a regular basis, to speed them up.

To see how much space apps, temporary files and documents are taking up, navigate to Settings > System > Storage. Tap Show more categories to see a full list.

4. Use background scrolling for multiple windows

In Windows 11, you can scroll up and down on any window you want. Even if it’s not the one you are working on. For example, if you want to open new sub-menu options in new windows to save you time click back and forward on the same page. 

The feature should be on by default, but if it isn’t, go to Settings > Bluetooth & devices > Mouse, and toggle Scroll inactive windows when I hover over them to On. Then you can place your mouse over a window that’s in the background and use the scroll wheel to scroll. 

5. Show file extensions in File Explorer

If you want to see a file extension in File Explorer, do the following

  • Using Search in the task bar, and type File Explorer Options, and click it.
  • In the window that pops up, click the View tab. 
  • If it’s checked, uncheck the box that says Hide extensions for known file types. Click Apply, and OK. You should now see file extensions for all files in the File Explorer. 

You can also use the File Explorer Options menu to choose to show empty drives, hidden files and folders, and more. 

The post Increase Your Windows 11 Experience With These 5 Hidden Features appeared first on The Tech Journalist.

item.title: Simply BEST & Elegant customization for Samsung devices Heres’s How
item.dc:creator: Jawad Hassan
item.description:
The easiest and simplest way to Customize your samsung device and give it an Elegant look and feel You need The Following Apps FineLock / Goodlock Go Parallax wallpaper Ultra Volume Control Styles (Full Unlocked version Free) KWGT Kustom Widget Maker With FineLock / Goodlock First go to Home UP then choose Home screen select […]

The post Simply BEST & Elegant customization for Samsung devices Heres’s How appeared first on The Tech Journalist.
item.content:encoded:
The easiest and simplest way to Customize your samsung device and give it an Elegant look and feel

You need The Following Apps

  • FineLock / Goodlock
  • Go Parallax wallpaper
  • Ultra Volume Control Styles (Full Unlocked version Free)
  • KWGT Kustom Widget Maker

With FineLock / Goodlock

First go to Home UP then choose Home screen select Home screen grid choose 7X7 or dial up to both 7’s & on Layout option deselect Hide app icon labels

Goodlock/Finelock>Home UP>Home screen>Home screen grid>7X7

& Layout>Hide app icon labels

With Go Parallax wallpaper

Now It’s time for the wallpapers A parallax wallpaper effect app is suggested then choose a wallpaper you want I am Using Pine forest then go to

With Ultra Volume Control Styles

*Remember your preview might not be same*

This part is easiest now Select any skin you like I am using Status Bar skin
NOW start the app Give ALL THE PERMISSION as it’s needed for the app to run

With KWGT Kustom Widget Maker

After opening the app you’ll be at Explore tab if not choose EXPLORE tab then search any widget you like I’ve chosen Base pack DigitalAndBattery. After selecting press on layers

The post Simply BEST & Elegant customization for Samsung devices Heres’s How appeared first on The Tech Journalist.

item.title: 3 Android settings to change now!
item.dc:creator: Jawad Hassan
item.description:
1.Apps having trouble showing notifications Go to settings search for Gmail app and stop battery optimizing Go to setting then search for optimise battery usage Then Tap on Apps not optimised (a drop down menu will drop) select All Now search for Gmail Tap on it (This might not fix the issue on your devices […]

The post 3 Android settings to change now! appeared first on The Tech Journalist.
item.content:encoded:
1.Apps having trouble showing notifications

Go to settings search for Gmail app and stop battery optimizing

  • Go to setting then search for optimise battery usage
  • Then Tap on Apps not optimised (a drop down menu will drop) select All
  • Now search for Gmail
  • Tap on it (This might not fix the issue on your devices so keep sync on from your notification center)
2. Make your android little faster

Check for running background apps from Developer options

*i.e this was tested on Android 11 device. we are not/will not take any responsible/ity if your device takes any damage*

  • Go to settings scroll down for developer option
  • If you don’t see it anywhere near About phone
  • Now enter Developer option scroll down all the way to Background Check or search it
  • Press on the option and deselect every app or package that is turned on

3.Turn of Nearby Device Scanning

  • Go to settings select Connections
  • Select More connection settings
  • Turn off Nearby device scanning

Leave your comment and search for more things that can directly or indirectly improve your life. Thanks!

The post 3 Android settings to change now! appeared first on The Tech Journalist.

item.title: Shanghai Fashion Week Highlights: The Shape of Things to Come
item.dc:creator: Jubayar
item.description:
We woke reasonably late following the feast and free flowing wine the night before. After gathering ourselves and our packs, we headed down to our homestay family’s small dining room for breakfast. Refreshingly, what was expected of her was the same thing that was expected of Lara Stone: to take a beautiful picture. We were […]

The post Shanghai Fashion Week Highlights: The Shape of Things to Come appeared first on The Tech Journalist.
item.content:encoded:
We woke reasonably late following the feast and free flowing wine the night before. After gathering ourselves and our packs, we headed down to our homestay family’s small dining room for breakfast.

Refreshingly, what was expected of her was the same thing that was expected of Lara Stone: to take a beautiful picture.

We were making our way to the Rila Mountains, where we were visiting the Rila Monastery where we enjoyed scrambled eggs, toast, mekitsi, local jam and peppermint tea.

We wandered the site with other tourists

Yet strangely the place did not seem crowded. I’m not sure if it was the sheer size of the place, or whether the masses congregated in one area and didn’t venture far from the main church, but I didn’t feel overwhelmed by tourists in the monastery.

Headed over Lions Bridge and made our way to the Sofia Synagogue, then sheltered in the Central Market Hall until the recurrent (but short-lived) mid-afternoon rain passed.

Feeling refreshed after an espresso, we walked a short distance to the small but welcoming Banya Bashi Mosque, then descended into the ancient Serdica complex.

We were exhausted after a long day of travel, so we headed back to the hotel and crashed.

I had low expectations about Sofia as a city, but after the walking tour I absolutely loved the place. This was an easy city to navigate, and it was a beautiful city – despite its ugly, staunch and stolid communist-built surrounds. Sofia has a very average facade as you enter the city, but once you lose yourself in the old town area, everything changes.

Clothes can transform your mood and confidence. Fashion moves so quickly that, unless you have a strong point of view, you can lose integrity. I like to be real. I don’t like things to be staged or fussy. I think I’d go mad if I didn’t have a place to escape to. You have to stay true to your heritage, that’s what your brand is about.

The post Shanghai Fashion Week Highlights: The Shape of Things to Come appeared first on The Tech Journalist.
